awd_titl_txt: Analysis and Recovery of High-Dimensional Data with Low-Dimensional Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Nowadays massive, high dimensional data sets arise in many fields of contemporary science and introduce new challenges. In machine learning, the well-known curse of dimensionality implies that, in order to achieve a fixed accuracy in prediction, a large number of training data is required. In image and signal recovery, a large number of measurements are needed to recover a high-dimensional vector, unless further assumptions are made. Fortunately, many real-world data sets exhibit low-dimensional geometric structures due to rich local regularities, global symmetries, repetitive patterns, or redundant sampling. The PI will explore low-dimensional geometric structures in data sets for feature extraction, data prediction and signal recovery. Dimension reduction and function approximation given a set of training data are of central interest in machine learning and data science. When data are concentrated near a low-dimensional set or the function has low complexity, the PI will develop new and fast machine learning algorithms whose performance depends on the complexity of the data or the function, instead of the dimension of the data sets.  In image and signal recovery, an interesting problem is to recover a high-dimensional, sparse vector from a small number of structured measurements. This problem is challenging since sensing matrices arising from imaging and signal processing are often deterministic, structured and highly coherent (some columns are highly correlated), which does not allow one to apply standard theory and algorithms. The PI will utilize the structures of sensing matrices, develop efficient algorithms, and prove performance guarantees. The theory and fast algorithms developed in this project can be applied to a wide range of problems in data compression, image analysis, computer vision, and signal recovery.
 
 
High dimensional data arise in many fields of contemporary science and introduce new challenges. Fortunately, many real-world data sets exhibit low-dimensional geometric structures. This project focuses on exploiting these low-dimensional geometric structures of the data sets, and developing novel methods for dimension reduction, function approximation, and signal recovery. The PI will work on two sets of problems. In the first one, a data set is modeled as point clouds in a D-dimensional space but concentrating near a d-dimensional manifold, where d is much smaller than D. She plans to exploit the geometric structures of the data sets to build low-dimensional representations of data and approximate functions on data. Function approximations in Euclidean spaces have been well studied; however, classical estimators converge to the true function extremely slowly in high dimensions. When data are concentrated near a d-dimensional manifold, or the function has low complexity, the PI aims at constructing estimators that converge to the true function at a faster rate depending on the intrinsic dimension d. The proposed approach is based on the PI's recent work on adaptive geometric approximations for intrinsically low-dimensional data, where a data-driven, fast and robust scheme was developed to construct low-dimensional geometric approximations of data. The second set of problems arise from imaging and signal processing where the goal is to recover a high-dimensional, sparse vector from its noisy low-frequency Fourier coefficients. It is related with super-resolution in imaging, as the missing high-frequency Fourier coefficients correspond to the high-resolution components of the vector. Many existing methods fail since some columns in the sensing matrix are highly correlated. The PI will utilize the structure of the sensing matrix, develop efficient algorithms and prove performance guarantees. A mathematical theory will be developed to explain the fundamental difficulty of super-resolution, as well as the resolution limit of superior subspace methods, such as MUSIC, ESPRIT, and the matrix pencil method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed solid mathematical theories and efficient algorithms to exploit low-dimensional structures of data sets, in machine learning, scientific computation, imaging and signal processing.

 

The PI worked on two sets of related but distinct problems. The first set is about exploiting the geometric structures of data sets when the given data are concentrated near a low-dimensional manifold. The PI has developed a robust and computationally efficient scheme to construct a family of multiscale low-dimensional geometric approximations of the given data. She applied this multiscale scheme to a broader set of problems, such as data compression, data prediction, and dictionary learning. Along this line of research, The PI started a new research direction on the performance of deep neural networks for data near a low-dimensional manifold. Mathematical theories on function approximation, regression, classification, and causal inference have been developed to demonstrate that deep neural networks are adaptive to the low-dimensional geometric structures of data.

 

The second set of problems is to recover a high-dimensional, sparse vector (a vector is said to be sparse if most entries are zero) from a small number of structured measurements with applications in imaging and signal processing. It has connections to compressive sensing and super-resolution. The PI has developed solid mathematical theories to understand the super-resolution limit, and the computational methods with super-resolution capability. Several open questions, such as the resolution limit of some superior subspace methods including MUSIC and ESPRIT, have been answered in the PI's publication. Her work has provided theories and guidelines for practitioners on experimental design and result interpretation of these subspace methods. In the area of inverse problems, the PI started a new research direction on the identification of unknown differential equations from noisy data. Given noisy data, the PI combined tools from machine learning and numerical PDEs to explore the dynamics of the given data, and robustly identify the sparse parameters in parametric PDEs, and the interaction kernel in non-local PDEs.

 

Major activities of this project are summarized below:

 

(1) This project has resulted in 16 articles, including 7 journal publications, 2 journal papers under revision, 3 journal papers under review, 3 conference proceedings and 1 preprint.

 

(2) The PI has been advising PhD student Minshuo Chen (Spring 2019 -  present) and Jiahui Cheng (Fall 2020 - present). Minshuo Chen is finishing his fourth year. He has published 9 papers on top machine learning conferences and has passed the thesis proposal. He attended NeurIPS 2019 and ICML 2021 (acceptance rate around 21%) to present his papers, respectively. Jiahui Cheng started PhD at Georgia Tech in Fall 2020. He has finished a preprint as a first author. This paper will be submitted to a top machine learning conference.

 

 

(3) The PI mentored postdoc Hao Liu (Fall 2018 - Spring 2021), who is now a tenure-track assistant professor at Hong Kong Baptist University.

 

(4) The PI has been actively engaged in undergraduate education. The PI has mentored 18 undergraduates with diverse backgrounds since 2017, including 7 women and 1 African American woman. Among them, 9 students participated in Georgia Tech's REU program, and 9 students worked with her during the semester. They are successful in their pursuits: one is working at Ernst & Young as a data scientist; 5 students are pursuing PhD at UCSD, USC, Chinese Academy of Sciences in China, Boston University and Georgia Tech.

 

(5) The PI has been actively engaged in data science education. She developed a new data science course entitled "Science Based Data Science" for students in the College of Science at Georgia Tech. This course serves as a Mathematical and Statistical Foundations of Data Science course for science majors. She designed the course materials including the lecture slides, homework assignments, and projects for this course, and taught it for the first time in Fall 2019.

 

(6) The PI has organized 3 mini-symposia in conferences and a workshop.

 

(7) The PI served as a technical program committee member in the SPARS conference, Toulouse, France, July 1-4, 2019, and oversaw paper reviews for this conference.

 

(8) The PI organized a machine learning reading group in the School of Mathematics at Georgia Tech in Fall 2018 and Spring 2019. There were about 15 regular participants consisting of graduate students, postdocs, and faculty members. This group met once a week to discuss selected papers.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2021
Modified by: Wenjing Liao
